summary: This document is a court filing from the civil case Jane Doe No. 2 v. Jeffrey Epstein, specifically the plaintiffs' reply in support of a motion to compel the FBI to produce sworn statements given by the plaintiffs (Jane Does 2-7) during the FBI's investigation of Epstein. It includes the motion, an affidavit from an attorney detailing her communications with the FBI, and a letter from FBI counsel outlining the Privacy Act requirements for releasing the statements. This document is a collection of filings and correspondence from the civil case Jane Doe 2-7 v. Jeffrey Epstein. It centers on the plaintiffs' motion to compel the FBI to produce sworn statements the plaintiffs gave during the FBI's criminal investigation of Epstein. The documents include the motion, a reply, affidavits, fax cover sheets, and internal emails between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office discussing the subpoena and the FBI's position that a court order or notarized consent is required under the Privacy Act. This document is a motion filed by plaintiffs Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 in civil lawsuits against Jeffrey Epstein, seeking to compel the FBI to release the plaintiffs' own sworn statements given during the FBI's criminal investigation of Epstein. It includes the motion, a subpoena, a proposed order, and related correspondence showing the FBI initially stated no responsive records were found. This document is a subpoena and related correspondence from the civil case 'Jane Does 2-7 v. Jeffrey Epstein' (Case No. 08-CV-80119). It includes a subpoena issued to the FBI's Records Custodian to produce sworn statements from six individuals (with redacted names but listed DOBs) taken during the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI's response, via a letter from Chief Division Counsel, cites regulations (28 CFR 16.21 et seq. and the Privacy Act) requiring a court order or notarized consent before releasing the requested records. Internal FBI notes document the receipt and handling of the subpoena.

events.title: Attorney contacts FBI for procedure
events.description: Attorney Jessica Arbour speaks with FBI Paralegal Specialist Deborah Moore to get instructions on obtaining her clients' sworn statements from the FBI investigation of Epstein. On the same day, a subpoena is served on the FBI.

events.title: FBI responds with Privacy Act requirements
events.description: FBI General Counsel (Frank Navas) sends a letter to Jessica Arbour confirming receipt of the subpoena and stating that release of the statements requires either notarized consent from each plaintiff or a court order due to the Privacy Act.

events.title: Plaintiffs file reply to motion to compel
events.description: Plaintiffs Jane Does 2-7 file a reply in support of their motion to compel the FBI to produce their sworn statements, arguing Epstein lacks standing to object and that they have followed the FBI's prescribed procedure.

events.title: FBI investigation of Epstein
events.description: The timeframe (approximately 2006-2007) during which the FBI investigated Jeffrey Epstein, leading to the sworn statements from the plaintiffs that are the subject of the subpoena.

events.title: Plaintiffs serve subpoena on FBI
events.description: Plaintiffs' counsel serves a subpoena duces tecum on the FBI Records Custodian for the sworn statements of Jane Doe Nos. 2-7, following instructions from FBI Paralegal Deborah Moore.

events.title: FBI responds to subpoena
events.description: FBI General Counsel (letter signed by John V. Gillies) sends a letter to Jessica Arbour stating the FBI's response is governed by the Privacy Act and requires either notarized consent from the plaintiffs or a court order.

events.title: Plaintiffs file Motion to Compel
events.description: Plaintiffs Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 file a Motion to Compel Production of their sworn statements from the FBI investigators, seeking a court order to comply with the Privacy Act.

events.title: Court grants motion to compel
events.description: The court issues an order granting the plaintiffs' motion to compel the FBI to produce the sworn statements. The FBI paralegal forwards this order to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: U.S. Attorney states no sworn statements exist
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney (for Jeffrey H. Sloman) sends a letter to Jessica Arbour stating that after contacting an FBI Special Agent, they advise that no sworn statements were taken from the six individuals listed in the subpoena.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Compel FBI Statements
events.description: Plaintiffs Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 file a motion to compel the FBI to release their sworn statements from the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Subpoena Served on FBI
events.description: A subpoena is served on the Records Custodian of the FBI's Miami office requesting sworn statements of Jane Doe Nos. 2-7.

events.title: Scheduled Production Date
events.description: The subpoena commands production of documents at Mermelstein & Horowitz's office by this date.

events.title: FBI Criminal Investigation of Epstein
events.description: Prior to the civil lawsuits, the FBI conducted a criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein during which Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 were interviewed.

events.title: Scheduled FBI Document Production
events.description: Date and time commanded in the subpoena for the FBI Records Custodian to produce documents at the law office of Mermelstein & Horowitz.

events.title: Subpoena and Request Letter Issued
events.description: The date of the subpoena and accompanying letter from plaintiff's attorneys to the FBI requesting documents.

events.title: FBI Response to Subpoena
events.description: The FBI, via Chief Division Counsel, faxed and mailed a response letter to attorney Jessica Arbour, citing CFR and Privacy Act regulations and requiring a court order for document release. The FBI also notified the U.S. Attorney's Office.

keyFacts: Plaintiffs' attorneys are seeking sworn statements that Jane Does 2-7 gave to the FBI during its investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, which took place approximately between 2006 and 2007.
The FBI informed the plaintiffs' attorney that releasing the statements requires compliance with the Privacy Act, specifically either notarized written consent from each plaintiff or a court order.
Defendant Jeffrey Epstein objected to the subpoena, but the plaintiffs argue he lacks standing to object to a subpoena directed at the non-party FBI.
The document reveals procedural steps in civil litigation to obtain evidence from a federal law enforcement agency, highlighting the tension between discovery rights and privacy statutes.
Multiple related civil cases (at least 12 case numbers are listed) are consolidated or related to the lead case, Jane Doe No. 2 v. Jeffrey Epstein.
Plaintiffs Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 are seeking their own sworn statements given to the FBI during the federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein for alleged childhood sexual battery.

The FBI's official position, stated in a March 16, 2010 letter, is that release of the statements is governed by the Privacy Act and requires either notarized consent from each plaintiff or a court order.

The U.S. Attorney's Office, in an April 13, 2010 letter, claims that after contacting the FBI case agent, they were advised that no sworn statements were taken from the six individuals listed in the subpoena.
The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to compel production of the statements on March 19, 2010, indicating a judicial order was issued to the FBI.

Internal FBI emails discuss the need for a declaration from the FBI case agent stating that no sworn statements exist, highlighting coordination between the FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office on the response.
Plaintiffs Jane Doe Nos. 2-7 are seeking their own sworn statements given to the FBI during the criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, citing the Federal Privacy Act.

The FBI initially informed plaintiffs' counsel that it required a court order to release the statements, but later correspondence indicates the FBI stated there were 'no sworn statements from the victims listed on Schedule A of the subpoena.'
The motion reveals there were multiple related civil cases (at least 13 case numbers listed) filed against Jeffrey Epstein for alleged childhood sexual battery.
The subpoena schedule A lists the birthdates of Jane Doe Nos. 2-7, indicating they were born between 1986 and 1990, making them teenagers or young adults during the alleged abuse period.
The document includes extensive service lists showing numerous attorneys involved in the litigation, indicating a complex, multi-party legal battle.

A subpoena was issued to the FBI's Records Custodian demanding production of sworn statements from six specific individuals (with listed dates of birth) taken during the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein in Palm Beach, FL.

The FBI formally declined immediate compliance, citing Title 28 CFR Section 16.21 et seq. (Touhy regulations) and the Privacy Act, requiring either a notarized consent from each record subject or a court order.
The document reveals the existence of sworn statements from at least six potential witnesses/victims (with DOBs ranging from 1986 to 1990) gathered during the criminal investigation of Epstein.
Internal FBI notes show the subpoena was received on March 15, 2010, and the response was coordinated with the U.S. Attorney's Office in Miami on March 16, 2010.
The civil case is identified as 'Jane Does 2-7 v. Jeffrey Epstein', Case No. 08-CV-80119, indicating multiple anonymous plaintiffs.
